    • MA598R—Summer 2007




Application Packages

Dec 3, 2010

The problem at hand is the following: a few months before graduation, a Ph.D. candidate usually sends hundreds of application packages to different universities, research institutions and companies, with the intention of gaining a profitable job. We all agree that the process is certainly painful: gathering reference letters, writing one (or several) research statement, teaching philosophy, and original cover letters. The aim is to make you stand out from the rest of candidates.

While I will not give you any hint on successful statement writing, or superb composition, I would like to show you how to accomplish the task of mass-producing a high-quality set of cover letters for all the jobs of your choice. The final product will comprise several copies of letters that look something like this:

Notice the structure of that letter: opening, a formal job request, short introduction, a big paragraph (where I may or may not include any text that makes the letter more personal), and finally a closing. Note also the fact that the letter carries the official logo and footer of the University. All this was accomplished directly in \( \LaTeX \), without the need to purchase special paper, or signing personally each letter.

We start by gathering the proper logo online from the official pages of the University, and your signature. For the latter, sign on a blank piece of paper with a bold pen (like a Sharpie), and take a photo of the signature:

Crop the signature from the photo, and by playing with exposure, saturation, contrast, brightness and color, manipulate it until it looks like a proper signature in black ink, over a perfectly white background:

For the next step, you need four \( \TeX \) files:

  • A class style defining the overall look of your letters,
  • a master file that runs the process of creation of the documents,
  • a data-base with the addresses and other particular information for each of the positions that you are applying, and
  • a cover letter form, where you actually use your creativity and composition prowess, to make a point across.

The cover letter form contains several variable fields, that must be filled with the data from the data-base. Upon compilation of the master file, we put it all together to obtain a different cover letter for each of the positions.

Let us go over the four documents in detail:

  • Class style: cover letter style for University of South Carolina, sclet.cls. It places the logo in the top left corner, the words “Department of Mathematics” and “College of Arts and Science” in the top right corner, a footer at the bottom of the page consisting on a burgundy horizontal line, followed below by the contact information of the University of South Carolina. It also indicates the margins of the document, possible font sizes, forces a justified alignment of paragraphs, etc.
  1 \DeclareOption*{\PassOptionsToClass{\CurrentOption}{letter}}
  2 
  3 \def\@checkoptions#1#2{
  4   \edef\@curroptions{\@ptionlist{\@currname.\@currext}}
  5   \@tempswafalse
  6   \@tfor\@this:=#2\do{
  7     \@expandtwoargs\in@{,\@this,}{,\@curroptions,}
  8     \ifin@ \@tempswatrue \@break@tfor \fi}
  9   \let\@this\@empty
 10   \if@tempswa \else \PassOptionsToClass{#1}{letter}\fi
 11 }
 12 
 13 \@checkoptions{12pt}{ {10pt}{11pt}{12pt} }
 14 \PassOptionsToClass{letterpaper}{letter}
 15 \ExecuteOptions{letterpaper,12pt,oneside,onecolumn,final}
 16 \ProcessOptions\relax
 17 
 18 \LoadClass{letter}
 19 \usepackage{graphicx}
 20 \usepackage{color}
 21 \ProvidesClass{sclet}[2010/12/05 University of South Carolina letter class]
 22 
 23 \setlength{\longindentation}{0pt}
 24 \setlength\headheight{18\p@}
 25 \setlength{\headsep}{.25in}
 26 \setlength{\evensidemargin}{\oddsidemargin}
 27 \font\helv=cmss12
 28 \font\helvsmall=cmss9
 29 
 30 \font\deptfont=pplr at 10truept
 31 \font\headfont=pplr at 10truept
 32 \definecolor{burgundy}{rgb}{0.50196,0,0.12549} 
 33 \addtolength{\topmargin}{-0.5pc}
 34 \addtolength{\oddsidemargin}{-3pc}
 35 \addtolength{\textwidth}{5.75in}
 36 
 37 \newif\ifcolorlogo \newcommand{\ColorLogo}{\colorlogotrue}
 38 \newcommand*{\fax}[1]{\def\faxnum{#1}}
 39 \newcommand*{\email}[1]{\def\emailaddr{#1}}
 40 \newcommand*{\url}[1]{\def\urladdr{#1}}
 41 \newcommand{\deptname}{\headfont {\sc Department of Mathematics}}
 42 \newcommand{\schoolname}{\headfont {\sc College of Arts and Sciences}}
 43 \newcommand{\deptfoot}{\deptfont{\ifcolorlogo\color{burgundy}\fi\hrulefill}
 44   \\ \raisebox{-1ex}{University of South Carolina
 45     $\bullet$ Columbia, South Carolina 29208  $\bullet$ \telephonenum\
 46     $\bullet$ Fax: \faxnum } }
 47 \renewcommand*{\opening}[1]{\ifx\@empty\fromaddress
 48   \thispagestyle{empty}
 49     {\relax}
 50   \else  
 51     \thispagestyle{empty}
 52     {\makebox[2.417in]{}\begin{tabular}{l@{}}\ignorespaces
 53       \fromaddress\end{tabular}\par}
 54   \fi
 55   \vspace{2\parskip}
 56   {\raggedright \toname \\ \toaddress \par}
 57   \vspace{2\parskip}
 58   #1\par\nobreak}
 59 \renewcommand{\ps@empty}{
 60    \renewcommand{\@oddhead}{
 61         \vbox{
 62            \ifcolorlogo
 63              \vskip-0.406in{
 64                \includegraphics[width=2.078125in]{usc_logo}
 65              }
 66            \else
 67              \vskip-1.420in\hskip-1.092in{
 68                \includegraphics[width=5.5cm]{usc_logo}
 69              }
 70            \fi
 71            \ifcase \@ptsize\relax
 72              \hskip1.9in{\deptname}
 73            \or
 74              \hskip1.9in{\deptname}
 75            \or
 76              \hskip1.9in{\deptname}
 77            \fi
 78            \ifcase \@ptsize\relax
 79              \flushright{\schoolname}
 80            \or
 81              \flushright{\schoolname}
 82            \or
 83              \flushright{\schoolname}
 84            \fi
 85         }
 86    }
 87    \renewcommand{\@oddfoot}{
 88         \vbox{
 89            \ifcase \@ptsize\relax
 90              \vskip1.263in\hskip-0.027in{\deptfoot}
 91            \or
 92              \vskip1.388in\hskip-0.027in{\deptfoot}
 93            \or
 94              \vskip1.290in\hskip-0.040in{\deptfoot}
 95            \fi

  • Master file: It could not be simpler.
 1 \documentclass[10pt]{sclet}
 2 
 3 \signature{\vskip-0.6in{\includegraphics[width=5.55cm]{signature.jpg}}\\
 4 Francisco Javier Blanco-Silva\\
 5 My address\\
 6 City, State, zip code}
 7 \textwidth = 6.25in
 8 \textheight = 8.5in
 9 \ColorLogo
10 
11 \begin{document}
12 \input cov.tex      
13 \input Addr.tex     
14 \end{document}
  • Database: The variable \cov is defined, as an entity with several fields (say 5 for the purposes of this example). The first entry is the address of the position, the second entry is the opening of the letter, the third entry is the name of the company/department, and finally the fifth entry is an optional paragraph. The collection of all possible positions is stored in the file Addr.tex, that looks something like this:
 1 \cov{     
 2 Hiring Committee\\
 3 Department of Mathematics\\
 4 School of Life\\
 5 Springflied, ST  50505
 6 }
 7 {Dear Professors:}
 8 {postdoctoral associate/part-time instructor positions}
 9 {the Department of Mathematics of the School of Life.}
10 {
11 Romani ad multas terras navigant aut ambulant. Saepe Romani in Europa
12 terras occupant. Hae terrae tum sunt provinciae Romae. Prima provincia
13 Romae erat Sicilia. Sicilia est insula. Multa aqua est circum Siciliam.
14 Romani ad Siciliam navigant et terram occupant. In Sicilia sunt multi
15 agricolae,et agricolae Siciliae Romanis cibum et praedam donant Provincia
16 Hispaniae est paeninsula. Provincia Hispaniae ad Romanos cibum et praedam
17 portat. Iulius Caesar Romanis fabulas pugnarum in Gallia in Commentarii
18 de Bello Gallico narrat. Etiam Caesar ad Britanniam navigat et pugnat, sed
19 tum Britannia non est provincia. Postea, imperator Claudius ad Brittaniam
20 navigat et Romanis terram mandat. Etiam Romania est provincia Romana.
21 Romani Romaniam provinciam Daciam appellant. Romani, vias et fora in
22 provinciis aedificant. Etiam provinciis linguam Latinam mandant.  In
23 provinciis Hispaniae, Galliae et Romaniae hodie linguae sunt "Linguae
24 Romanae".
25 }
26 
27 \cov{ ...
  • Cover letter form: The file cov.tex, where we define the entity \cov, and start a letter in the usual \( \LaTeX \) way.
 1 \newcommand{\cov}[5]
 2 {
 3 \begin{letter}{#1}
 4 \opening{#2}
 5 
 6 [First paragraph, declaration of intentions]
 7 This letter is in regards to the formal submission of my application
 8 for the {#3} currently open at {#4}
 9 
10 [Second paragraph, introduction of myself and my work.]
11 I completed my doctorate in [...] and many questions remain open.
12 
13 [Third paragraph, I sell myself a little]
14 I have a very ample experience in teaching: I have had the opportunity
15 [...] All these are also available at \url{blancosilva.wordpress.com}
16 
17 [Fourth paragraph, I get a little personal.]
18 {#5}
19 
20 [And closing.  Give contact info.]
21 I look forward to discussing the qualifications for the position
22 further. [...] Thank you for your consideration.
23 
24 \closing{Sincerely,}
25 \deptfoot
26 \end{letter}
27 }
